text: And in the second month, on the seven and twentieth day of the month, was the earth dried.
text_kjv: And in the second month, on the seven and twentieth day of the month, was the earth dried.
text_niv: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month the earth was completely dry.
text_esv: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth had dried out.
text_nlt: Two more months went by, and at last the earth was dry!
text_msg: By the twenty-seventh day of the second month, the Earth was completely dry.
text_nasb: In the second month, on the twenty-seventh day of the month, the earth was dry.
context: Genesis 8:14 is a simple statement of fact, yet it's pregnant with historical and cultural significance. Understanding the ancient Near Eastern worldview is crucial. The flood narrative wasn't unique to the Hebrews; similar stories existed in Mesopotamian cultures (e.g., the Epic of Gilgamesh), suggesting a shared cultural memory, possibly of a devastating regional flood. However, the Genesis account uniquely frames the flood theologically, as divine judgment and subsequent redemption. Calendars in the ancient world were luni-solar, meaning they were based on both the cycles of the moon and the sun. The 'second month' likely refers to the second month after the Ark landed, following the lunar calendar used at the time. The specific date, the 'twenty-seventh day,' highlights the meticulous record-keeping, emphasizing the historicity and reality of the event. The phrase 'the earth was dried' signifies not just the disappearance of water but also the end of God's judgment and the beginning of a new era. It anticipates the repopulation of the earth and the re-establishment of God's covenant with humanity through Noah. The land's readiness was critical for survival after such devastation; seeds would have to be planted promptly to reestablish a sustainable food supply, highlighting God's provision and timing.
meaning: Theologically, Genesis 8:14 carries profound implications. It marks the culmination of God's judgment upon a wicked world and the commencement of a new beginning predicated on grace. The verse emphasizes the sovereignty of God over creation. God, who initiated the flood as a response to human wickedness (Genesis 6:5-7), is the same God who brings the flood to an end. The drying of the earth represents God's restorative power. It signifies the re-establishment of order from chaos. While the flood was an act of divine wrath, its conclusion demonstrates God's commitment to preserving humanity and the created order. The specific timing underscores God's meticulous planning and faithful execution of His promises. He is not arbitrary but acts according to His righteous character. The verse points towards the concept of covenant. Even after the flood, God's covenant with Noah (Genesis 9) demonstrates His unwavering commitment to preserving life and promising never to destroy the earth again by flood. This verse is also a shadow of future salvation. Just as the flood cleansed the earth, baptism symbolizes the cleansing of sins. Just as Noah and his family emerged to a new earth, believers emerge to a new life in Christ. Therefore, Genesis 8:14 is not simply a statement of physical reality; it's a theological declaration of God's power, faithfulness, and promise of renewal.
application: The drying of the earth in Genesis 8:14 offers several practical applications for modern living. Firstly, it teaches us about patience and trust in God's timing. Noah and his family waited months inside the ark, trusting that God would bring about the end of the flood in His own time. Similarly, we are often called to wait on God's timing in our lives, even when we don't understand His plan. Secondly, it reminds us of the importance of new beginnings. The drying of the earth symbolized a fresh start for humanity. We too can experience new beginnings through repentance, forgiveness, and faith in Christ. God offers us the opportunity to leave behind our past mistakes and embrace a future filled with hope and purpose. Thirdly, it highlights the significance of preparation. Noah diligently followed God's instructions in building the ark and gathering animals. Likewise, we should prepare ourselves spiritually, emotionally, and practically for whatever challenges life may bring. This includes developing a strong relationship with God, cultivating resilience, and acquiring the skills and resources we need to navigate difficult circumstances. Fourthly, it encourages us to appreciate the goodness of God's creation. After the flood, Noah offered a sacrifice of thanksgiving to God, acknowledging His provision and protection. We should also cultivate a sense of gratitude for the beauty and abundance of God's world, and strive to be good stewards of His creation. Finally, the verse calls us to action. The drying of the earth meant that Noah and his family could finally leave the ark and begin the work of rebuilding their lives and repopulating the earth. Similarly, we are called to be active participants in God's kingdom, using our gifts and talents to serve others and make a positive impact on the world.
prayer: Heavenly Father, we thank you for your sovereignty over all creation. We praise you for your faithfulness in fulfilling your promises. Thank you for bringing the flood to an end and drying the earth, signaling a new beginning for humanity. Lord, help us to trust in your timing, even when we don't understand your plan. Give us the patience to wait on you and the faith to believe that you are working all things together for our good. Grant us the grace to embrace new beginnings, to leave behind our past mistakes, and to walk in newness of life. Help us to appreciate the beauty and abundance of your creation, and to be good stewards of all that you have entrusted to us. Lord, empower us to use our gifts and talents to serve others and to make a positive impact on the world. We ask all these things in the name of Jesus Christ, our Lord. Amen.

faqs.answer: Why is the specific date mentioned (the twenty-seventh day)? The detail emphasizes the factual nature of the event and God's precise control over creation. It underscores the reality of the flood, unlike mere mythical stories. The record keeping confirms that this was an actual event.
faqs.question: Q1 about this verse

faqs.answer: How does this verse relate to the concept of covenant? This verse comes just before God makes a covenant with Noah. The dried earth is the stage upon which the covenant can be enacted, symbolizing a fresh start for humankind and God's enduring faithfulness.
faqs.question: Q2

faqs.answer: What significance does 'the earth was dried' have in relation to sacrifice? A dried earth allowed Noah to offer a sacrifice, which pleased God. It highlights the importance of worship and thanksgiving to God after deliverance. It represents restoration of right relationship.
faqs.question: Q3

faqs.answer: How might a modern environmentalist interpret 'the earth was dried'? They may see it as a reminder of the Earth's resilience and ability to recover from disasters, yet also as a call to be responsible stewards to prevent future calamities. Conservation is key.
faqs.question: Q4

faqs.answer: Is there a symbolic meaning to the duration of the flood and the drying process? Some see parallels to spiritual cycles: periods of testing and judgment followed by restoration and renewal. The length implies a thorough cleansing before rebirth, symbolically and literally.
